page.title: 02THE VILLAGE OF THRESHFIELD
page.content: { {Threshfield}is a typical Anglian name given by the people who came to this country during the{4th}to{7th {centuries A.D.}Long before{Threshfield had a humpbacked bridge there was a {ford}for cars to go through. The first written records of{Threshfield}are in {The Domesday Book 1087}and are very short and brief. At{Threshfield}in the year{1087}there were{8}families but when they looked again in{1285}there were{12}families.{Threshfield}means {'Threshing field.'}The name probably arose for an outlying, small Hamlet when{Grassington}expanded. Later it grew into an independant village with its own cultivated fields. Today{Threshfield}is a village of some {200}families with the majority of people working away from the area.
